unnormalised: Okay, here's a Quora post on Training Regimens in Sports:
normalised: What is the deal with different training regimens in sports? It all seems so complicated!

unnormalised: **What's the deal with different training regimens in sports? It all seems so complicated!**
normalised: Hey folks! Been hitting the gym again and wondering about the best way to train? It is true, there is a lot out there about training regimens, and it can feel overwhelming, especially if you are just starting out.

unnormalised: Hey folks! Been hitting the gym again and wondering about the best way to train? It's true, there's a *lot* out there about training regimens, and it can feel overwhelming, especially if you're just starting out.
normalised: The key thing to remember is that the "best" regimen is super dependent on your sport and goals. What works for P V Sindhu in badminton won't necessarily work for a cricket fast bowler like Jasprit Bumrah.

unnormalised: The key thing to remember is that the "best" regimen is super dependent on your sport and goals. What works for PV Sindhu in badminton won't necessarily work for a cricket fast bowler like Jasprit Bumrah.
normalised: For example, if you are training for a marathon like the Mumbai Marathon (held annually in January, I think next year's date is around January twenty first, two thousand and twenty five?), you will be focusing on long-distance endurance, right? Think long, slow runs, maybe a thirty kilometer run every other week, strength training to prevent injuries, and carb-loading the day before the big run.

unnormalised: For example, if you're training for a marathon like the Mumbai Marathon (held annually in January, I think next year's date is around January 21st, 2025?), you'll be focusing on long-distance endurance, right? Think long, slow runs, maybe a 30 km run every other week, strength training to prevent injuries, and carb-loading the day before the big run.
normalised: On the other hand, if you are training for powerlifting, it is all about short bursts of maximum effort. You would be doing heavy squats, bench presses, and deadlifts. I remember reading about Satnam Singh Bhamara's training schedule back in two thousand and fifteen - intense weightlifting sessions twice a day, plus basketball practice!

normalised: And don't forget about recovery! Sleep, nutrition (dal-chawal is surprisingly good fuel!), and active recovery (like yoga at zero six hundred hours every morning, as my grandma recommends!) are all critical. You can't just hammer away at training seven days a week. Overtraining is a real thing!

normalised: Ultimately, the best advice I can give is to consult with a qualified coach. They can assess your fitness level, understand your goals (maybe getting into the Indian Institute of Sports someday?), and create a personalized training plan that is right for you. Happy training!
